facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 424 of 1960 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Civil Appeal No. 424 of 1960.

facts.text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 25, 1958, of the Madras High Court in case Referred No. 62 of 1957.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated March 25, 1958, of the Madras High Court in case Referred No. 62 of 1957. V. Viswanatha Sastri, J. B. Dadachanji, Rameshwar Nath and P. L. Vohra, for the appellant.

facts.text: Judgment of the Court delivered by KAPUR, J. on March 13, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: 1961. March 13. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Madras.

facts.text: The assessee is the appellant and the Commissioner of Income-tax is the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The Judgment of the Court was delivered by KAPUR, J.-This is an appeal against the judgment and order of the High Court of Judicature at Madras. The assessee is the appellant and the Commissioner of Income-tax is the respondent.

facts.text: A partnership consisting of four persons was formed by a deed of partnership dated March 31, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: A partnership companysisting of four persons was formed by a deed of partnership dated March 31, 1949. On July 27, 1951 another partner was taken into partnership and a new deed was drawn up.

facts.text: On July 27, 1951 another partner was taken into partnership and a new deed was drawn up.

anchor.surface_text: On July 27, 1951 another partner was taken into partnership and a new deed was drawn up. The previous partnership deed was companysidered as the principal deed.

facts.text: The new partnership like the old one was to end on March 31, 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The previous partnership deed was companysidered as the principal deed. The new partnership like the old one was to end on March 31, 1954.

facts.text: On March 29, 1954, a new partnership was entered into and a sixth partner was taken and a new deed was executed.

anchor.surface_text: On March 29, 1954, a new partnership was entered into and a sixth partner was taken and a new deed was executed. The new partner companytributed Rs. 40,000 as his share to the capital

facts.text: The new partner contributed Rs. 40,000 as his share to the capital.

anchor.surface_text: The new partner companytributed Rs. 40,000 as his share to the capital but in the partnership deed numberexpress provision was made as to the manner in which profits and losses were to be divided between the partners.

facts.text: In the partnership deed dated March 29, 1954 no express provision was made as to the manner in which profits and losses were to be divided between the partners.

anchor.surface_text: but in the partnership deed numberexpress provision was made as to the manner in which profits and losses were to be divided between the partners. In order to rectify this, a deed of rectification was executed on September 17, 1955,

facts.text: A deed of rectification was executed on September 17, 1955, which was after the close of the account year 1954-55.

anchor.surface_text: In order to rectify this, a deed of rectification was executed on September 17, 1955, which was after the close of the account year 1954-55. This deed recited that an error had crept in

facts.text: The deed of rectification recited that an error had crept in in typing the partnership deed dated March 29, 1954 by omitting to type cl. 21 of the old partnership deed.

anchor.surface_text: This deed recited that an error had crept in in typing the partnership deed dated March 29, 1954 by omitting to type el. 21 of the old partnership deed in the new deed.

facts.text: The deed of rectification added clause 20-A specifying shares in profits and losses in proportion to capital contribution.

anchor.surface_text: The parties had therefore agreed to rectify the error by adding cl. 20- A as follows- We hereby agree that for purpose of clarification the following clause shall be added as clause 20-A in the Partnership Instrument, dated 29th March, 1954- The parties shall be entitled to shares in the profits and losses of the firm in proportion to the companytribution of the capital of each of the partners

facts.text: Up to the end of assessment year 1954-55 the old firms i.e., the one constituted of four partners and the other constituted of five partners were registered under s. 26A of the Income Tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: Up to the end of assessment year 1954-55 the old firms i.e., the one companystituted of four partners and the other companystituted of five partners were registered under s. 26A of the Income Tax Act  hereinafter termed the Act .

facts.text: The appellant firm applied for registration for the assessment year 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant firm then applied for registration for the assessment year 1955-56. The Income Tax Officer pointed out to the appellant firm that there was numberspecification of shares of the partners

facts.text: Income Tax Officer refused registration because there was no specification of shares of the partners in the deed of partnership.

anchor.surface_text: The Income Tax Officer pointed out to the appellant firm that there was numberspecification of shares of the partners in the deed of partnership. Thereupon the appellant submitted the deed of rectification dated September 17, 1955,

facts.text: Appellant submitted the deed of rectification dated September 17, 1955 and claimed it clarified the original deed.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellant submitted the deed of rectification dated September 17, 1955, above mentioned and submitted that the original deed did specify the shares of the partners and the deed of rectification only clarified the position.

facts.text: Registration was refused by the Income-tax Officer.

anchor.surface_text: But the registration was refused by the Income-tax Officer and an appeal taken against that order to the Assistant Commissioner was dismissed.

facts.text: Appeal against ITO order to Assistant Commissioner was dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: But the registration was refused by the Income-tax Officer and an appeal taken against that order to the Assistant Commissioner was dismissed. Further appeal was taken to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which also failed.

facts.text: Appeal to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal failed.

anchor.surface_text: Further appeal was taken to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which also failed. At the request of the appellant the following question was referred to the High Court for its opinion-

facts.text: Question referred to High Court: Whether the assessee firm is entitled to registration u/s 26A for 1955-56.

anchor.surface_text: At the request of the appellant the following question was referred to the High Court for its opinion- Whether the assessee firm is entitled to registration u s. 26-A of the Income-tax Act for the assessment year 1955-56.

facts.text: High Court held that factual existence in the year of account of an instrument of partnership specifying shares was necessary, which was lacking.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that under s. 26-A of the Act the factual existence in the year of account of an instrument of partnership was necessary, a requisite which, in the present case, was lacking

facts.text: High Court held specification of shares took place only on September 17, 1955 when deed of rectification executed.

anchor.surface_text: and therefore the provisions of s. 26-A were number satisfied and that the specification of shares only took place on September 17, 1955 when the deed of rectification was executed.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Supreme Court by certificate of High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The question was therefore answered in the negative. Against this judgment and order the appellant has companye in appeal to this Court by certificate of the High Court.

facts.text: Appellant contended that clauses 9, 11, 34 and 41a sufficiently specified the shares of the partners.

anchor.surface_text: It was companytended that cls. 9, 11, 34 and 41 a  sufficiently specified the shares of the partners and satisfied the requirements of the law.

facts.text: Court held that none of clauses 9, 11, 34, 41a specify the shares of the partners in profits and losses.

anchor.surface_text: None of these clauses specify the shares of the partners. Clause 9 has reference to extra companytribution made by the partners which was to be treated as capital companytribution for the purpose of dividing profits but was number otherwise taken to be paid up capital.

facts.text: Supreme Court held registration under s. 26A was rightly refused because instrument did not specify individual shares of partners during year of account.

issues.text: Whether cls. 9, 11, 34 and 41(a) sufficiently specified the shares of the partners in profits and losses

anchor.surface_text: It was contended that cls. 9, 11, 34 and 41 a  sufficiently specified the shares of the partners and satisfied the requirements of the law. These clauses were as follows- Cl. 9 Such extra contribution made by the partners shall be credited to the respective partners under an account called Extra Capital Subscription Account and for the period of the utilisation of the whole or part thereof during the course of the year or years, it shall be treated as capital contribution only for the purpose of dividing profit but it shall otherwise in no circumstances be added to the paid-up capital.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that under s. 26-A of the Act the factual existence in the year of account of an instrument of partnership was necessary, a requisite which, in the present case, was lacking and therefore the provisions of s. 26-A were not satisfied and that the specification of shares only took place on September 17, 1955 when the deed of rectification was executed.

arguments.claim: Registration under s. 26-A confers a benefit which must be claimed strictly in accordance with the statute; person seeking relief must bring himself strictly within the terms of the section.

anchor.surface_text: Registration under s. 26-A of the Act confers a benefit on the partners which the partners would not be entitled to but for s. 26-A. The right can be claimed only in accordance with the statute which confers it and a person seeking relief under that section must bring himself strictly within the term of that section.

arguments.claim: Firm must be constituted under an instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners to qualify under s. 26A.

anchor.surface_text: The right is strictly regulated by the terms of that statute Ravula Subba Rao v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras Section 26-A provides- S.26A 1  Application may be made to the Income-tax Officer on behalf of any firm, constituted under an instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners for registration for the purpose of this Act

arguments.claim: The instrument of partnership to be registered should have been in existence in the accounting year in respect of which assessment is being made; firms must strictly comply with requirements.

anchor.surface_text: In B. C. Mitter Sons V. Commissioner of Income- tax  2  it was held that the instrument of partnership to be registered should have been in existence in the accounting year in respect of which an assessment is being made. At page 202, Sinha J.,  as he then was  said-

arguments.claim: In the present case, instrument existed but did not specify shares during accounting year; condition fulfilled only by rectification deed dated September 17, 1955.

holdings.text: None of these clauses specify the shares of the partners.

anchor.surface_text: None of these clauses specify the shares of the partners. Clause 9 has reference to extra contribution made by the partners which was to be treated as capital contribution for the purpose of dividing profits but was not otherwise taken to be paid up capital. Clause 11 provides for interest on the extra capital subscribed-. Clause 34 authorises the senior partner during the subsistence of the partnership to bring in one or more of his sons as partners who on being so brought in were entitled to remuneration and profits in proportion to their capital contribution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Examination of clauses 9 (extra contribution treated as capital for profit division but not paid-up capital), 11 (interest on extra capital), 34 (new partners entitled in proportion to capital), 41a (capital return on dissolution in proportion to contribution) shows no specification of fixed shares in profits and losses.

holdings.text: In none of these clauses is it stated what the shares of the partners in the profits and losses of the firm were to be and that in our opinion was requisite for registration of the partnership under s. 26-A of the Act and as that was wanting, registration was rightly refused.

anchor.surface_text: But in none of these clauses is it stated what the shares of the partners in the profits and losses of the firm were to be and that in our opinion was requisite for registration of the partnership under s. 26-A of the Act and as that was wanting, registration was rightly refused.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Absence of statement of partners' shares in profits and losses in the deed violates s. 26A requirement for registration.

holdings.text: Registration under s. 26-A of the Act confers a benefit on the partners which the partners would not be entitled to but for s. 26-A. The right can be claimed only in accordance with the statute which confers it and a person seeking relief under that section must bring himself strictly within the term of that section.

anchor.surface_text: Registration under s. 26-A of the Act confers a benefit on the partners which the partners would not be entitled to but for s. 26-A. The right can be claimed only in accordance with the statute which confers it and a person seeking relief under that section must bring himself strictly within the term of that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Benefit of registration is statutory and requires strict compliance with section terms, citing Ravula Subba Rao precedent.

holdings.text: Unless the instrument of partnership specified the individual shares of the partners the instrument of partnership does not conform to the requirements of the section.

anchor.surface_text: The right is strictly regulated by the terms of that statute Ravula Subba Rao v. The Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras Section 26-A provides- S.26A 1  Application may be made to the Income-tax Officer on behalf of any firm, constituted under an instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners for registration for the purpose of this Act

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct textual reading of s. 26A requires constitution under instrument specifying individual shares of partners.

holdings.text: The instrument of partnership to be registered should have been in existence in the accounting year in respect of which an assessment is being made.

anchor.surface_text: In B. C. Mitter Sons V. Commissioner of Income- tax  2  it was held that the instrument of partnership to be registered should have been in existence in the accounting year in respect of which an assessment is being made. At page 202, Sinha J.,  as he then was  said-

holdings.reasoning_summary: Adopts precedent from B.C. Mitter & Sons that instrument specifying shares must factually exist during relevant accounting year for registration.

holdings.text: In the present case an instrument of partnership was in existence but it did not specify the shares which was one of the requirements for registration and that condition was fulfilled by the deed of rectification dated September 17, 1955. Therefore it cannot be said that there was the requisite instrument of partnership specifying the individual shares of the partners during the year of account.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies rules to facts: deed of March 29, 1954 existed but lacked share specification until post-account-year rectification on September 17, 1955.

holdings.text: The High Court, in our opinion, was right in answering the question in the negative.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, in our opinion, was right in answering the question in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affirms High Court's negative answer to whether assessee entitled to registration u/s 26A for 1955-56 based on cumulative analysis.
